message: Today marks the first day for the 115th Congress and we are ready to hit the ground running. #OpeningDay Watch live online at 3pm on c-span.org or speaker.gov/live.
NA
NA
NA

Everyday, our police officers answer the call of duty without hesitation to protect and serve the people of Southern and Eastern Kentucky. In honor of #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay, thank you for your service!

Today, I was selected to serve as Chairman of the U.S. House Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations and Related Agencies for the 115th Congress.   Click the link to read more about my role as a congressional international ambassador.

I have the honor of serving on three U.S. House Appropriations Subcommittees during the 115th Congress. In addition to being tapped as Chairman of the U.S. House Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations and Related Agencies, I will also serve as a member of the Subcommittees on Defense and Commerce, Justice and Science.   The three combined committees are responsible for the oversight of more than $625 billion in discretionary spending for our national security, military operations, economic development, science and space research, as well as federal law enforcement and illegal drug efforts. It is an honor to return to these subcommittees, as we work to get our fiscal house in order and strengthen this great nation.  Click the link below for more information.
NA

I am excited for the entire country to hear Eastern Kentucky's own Marlana VanHoose sing during the Presidential Inaugural events in Washington, D.C. She is incredibly talented and makes all of us very proud. Congratulations Marlana!
Proud of our talented students from Northern Middle School in Pulaski County who will be singing during the Presidential Inaugural Concert in Washington, D.C. on Thursday!

I'm pleased to welcome all of our Kentucky friends to Washington, D.C. for the 58th Presidential Inauguration festivities this week. Enjoy this historic moment in our nation's history!  Click the link below for details about each event. #TrumpInaugural

Tune in to WKYT beginning today at 4:30 p.m. to see coverage of the 58th Presidential Inaugural events this week. I enjoyed chatting with Sam Dick WKYT earlier today about priorities for the new Congress and working with President-elect Trump.

I am extremely proud of Pulaski County's Northern Middle School Honors Choir for their beautiful performance of "My Old Kentucky Home" at the Presidential Inaugural Concert today at the Lincoln Memorial! You represented southern and eastern Kentucky with great class. #TrumpInaugural

WATCH the Swearing-In Ceremony of Donald J. Trump LIVE ‚Üí http://58pic2017.org #MAGA #TrumpInaugural  And follow on social media for the latest: Twitter: https://twitter.com/TrumpInaugural Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/trumpinaugural/
Excellent job as always, Marlana VanHoose! Thank you for representing Eastern Kentucky with such grace and talent.
NA

With a peaceful transfer of power to President Trump now complete, let us unite as a nation and move forward with the same determination and resolve that built the foundation of our freedom and democracy.   President Trump offered encouraging words of solidarity and restoration of power to the American people.  As we look forward to the next four years, we must be diligent in our efforts to strengthen our national security, provide an affordable and efficient healthcare system, support innovative tax reform that will spur economic development, and ultimately build a better future for our children and grandchildren.   The hope of a better future in our communities is anchored by the men and women who remain steadfast in their actions at the local level, through grassroots initiatives like SOAR - Shaping Our Appalachian Region, as we work together to revitalize our economy in the coalfields of Eastern Kentucky, with support and relief from Washington.   I'm eager to work alongside President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence to rebuild and restore the promises of this great nation. #TrumpInaugural
NA

Congratulations to John Garland, Mary Katherine Grippe and Abigail Scott - students at Somerset Christian School - for earning silver and bronze medals through The Congressional Award program! Click the link to learn more.

I have been a long-time defender of the millions of innocent babies whose lives are abruptly ended every year in America.   We need to roll back the heart-breaking policies that were made in the final hours of the Obama Administration and restore the sanctity of life in this country.   Each state should have the authority to provide funding to for effective healthcare, rather than being forced to use taxpayer dollars for abortions.   Click the link below to learn more about our pro-life legislation.

Today, the U.S House of Representatives passed a resolution to overturn the Obama Administration's Stream Buffer Zone Rule threatening one-third of the nation's coal mining jobs. Click the video link to learn more about this job-saving resolution.
Honored to have Kentucky Speaker of the House Jeff Hoover as my guest this morning for the annual National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, DC. Please join us in prayer for our great nation.

Every 20 minutes, someone in America dies from an opioid overdose, according to the CDC.   In an effort to combat the drug abuse epidemic and continue life-saving efforts across the country, I'm proud to join my friend and colleage across the aisle, Representative Stephen F. Lynch (D-Mass.) to re-launch the bi-partisan Congressional Caucus on Prescription Drug Abuse. Read more about the Caucus by clicking the link below.

The White House will reopen for public tours on March 7th.   If you live in southern and eastern Kentucky and plan to visit the White House this year, please contact my office to submit your request.   Tour requests can be made up to three months in advance and must be submitted no less than 21 days in advance.  Click the link below for public hours and information.

Earlier today, President Trump issued an executive order to review the Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule.  I applaud President Trump for his determination to roll back this extreme power grab by the Obama administration. The WOTUS rule would give unelected bureaucrats the authority to hand out costly fines for any unapproved dirt-moving activity ‚Äî from farming to private land construction. This formal review is the first step to cut through the red tape currently restricting our nation‚Äôs miners, farmers, small business owners and hard working Americans.

I'm incredibly proud to join Senator Mitch McConnell, Senator Shelley Moore Capito and my colleagues in the U.S. House, Congressman Matt Cartwright, Rep. Evan Jenkins, Congressman Morgan Griffith and Rep. Glenn Thompson to introduce the RECLAIM Act of 2017.   Over the last eight years, we‚Äôve lost more than 13,000 coal mining jobs in Kentucky alone, and through this bill, we have an incredible opportunity to make sure that our coal producing states can access funding that is readily available to restore our land and revive our economy. Click the link to read more! #RECLAIM

Happy 14th Anniversary to Operation UNITE! I'm incredibly proud of UNITE's holistic efforts - growing from a rural grassroots initiative into a national model for success - to address the drug abuse epidemic across the country.  ------------  Operation UNITE was incorporated on this date in 2003. UNITE was created by Congressman Hal Rogers in response to a special report, ‚ÄúPrescription for Pain,‚Äù published by the Lexington Herald-Leader.  More than 100,000 youth have participated in UNITE‚Äôs programs, tens of thousands of community members have volunteered, and more than 4,000 people have entered treatment using a UNITE voucher.  We thank the thousands of community members for their leadership, service and advocacy to fight the drug epidemic. And a special thank-you to our initial directors: Mr. Bob Mitchell  Mr. Tom Handy Mr. Steve Hanson Chief Elijah Hollon Sheriff Pat Wooten

Special thanks to these champions in the fight against drug abuse for sharing their expertise at the National Rx Drug Abuse Summit. I look forward to hearing remarks from Senator Edward J. Markey, Congressman Buddy Carter, HHS Secretary Tom Price, M.D., The National Institute on Drug Abuse - NIDA Director Nora Volkow, Governor Matt Bevin and Acting Director of the ONDCP Richard Baum.

I'm incredibly proud of the Board of Directors for Operation UNITE for pioneering the effort to bring the drug abuse epidemic into the national spotlight through the National Rx Drug Abuse Summit. Thank you for continuing this life-saving work!

Congratulations to the Advisory Board of the National Rx Drug Abuse Summit for putting together the 6th and largest conference to combat the nation's drug abuse epidemic. With nearly 2,400 attendees from four countries and a wide spectrum of stakeholders, we are actively working to share innovative ideas and effective solutions to save lives across the country. Keep up the great work! Operation UNITE
‚Ä™Pleased to welcome @StateINL Ambassador William Brownfield to the National Rx Drug Abuse Summit to talk about international engagement on drug abuse.‚Ä¨

This morning, at the National Rx Drug Abuse Summit, Senator Edward J. Markey warns about the rapid rise in fentanyl deaths across the country, specifically in his home state of Massachusetts where fatal fentanyl overdoses jumped from 900 in 2015 to 1,500 in 2016.

It's an honor to have these powerful speakers at the 6th Annual National Rx Drug Abuse Summit this morning as we work through the challenges of addiction to save lives across the country.   Special thanks to my friends for sharing their expertise and personal stories this morning: former Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich; former Congressman Patrick J. Kennedy; Dr. Francis Collins, Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH); Dr. Anne Schuchat, Acting Director of the CDC; and Acting Commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Stephen Ostroff.   As Mr. Kennedy said this morning, we need to build upon our infrastructure to combat addiction with better "roads to recovery and bridges to health."  Operation UNITE #RxSummit2017

Later this week, Congress will vote on the FY17 Omnibus Appropriations bill to fund the nation's priorities, including important programs for coal communities and health benefits for retired coal miners.   Specifically, it includes a permanent fix for health care benefits for retired coal miners, their widows and other dependents. It also provides $105 million for a second round of funding for the Abandoned Mine Lands (AML) Pilot Program, which will enable participating states to reclaim AML sites in conjunction with economic development projects. Under the pilot, Kentucky will receive an additional $25 million in 2017. The Omnibus also includes $30 million for the Economic Development Administration to support coal communities and funds the ARC at historic levels. $152 million in ARC funding includes $10 million for high-speed broadband deployment in distressed central Appalachian communities. Finally, the legislation will help put miners back to work by taking important steps to help the coal industry rebound after eight years of job-killing regulations under President Obama.  Our coal communities and coal miners have suffered the heavy burden of financial insecurity for far too long. Retired coal miners can now rest assured that their medical needs will be met, along with their wives and children. They worked long and hard to power this great nation and we should uphold our commitment to take care of them. Likewise, our coal mining communities in Kentucky are working diligently to rebuild after losing more than 13,000 mining jobs over the last eight years. This legislation will provide funding to boost economic development in our coalfields and create jobs where we need them the most.  Click the link below to read more.

Congress passed the 2017 Omnibus Appropriations bill this week to fund the federal government through September 30, 2017. I voted for the legislation that funds the nation's priorities and fulfills the promise of the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act (CARA) and the 21st Century Cures Act by including an increase of $781 million over current levels to fight the opioid epidemic.   Great strides have been made in combatting drug abuse in southern and eastern Kentucky; however, still too many lives are lost each year to accidental overdoses. One person dies every ten minutes from a drug overdoes in America, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), so we must continue the multi-pronged approach in this life-saving mission to stop illegal drug sales, prevent abuse and properly treat addiction.  Click the link to see specific examples of measures to help save lives and prevent generational drug abuse trends.

Today, President Trump released his proposed budget for fiscal year 2018, entitled: A New Foundation for American Greatness.  President Trump proposed an aggressive budget to beef up our national defense, while also working to balance federal spending over the long run. It includes important funding for priorities like immigration enforcement and combatting the nation‚Äôs opioid epidemic, while also preserving Social Security and Medicare benefits for our most vulnerable.   However, the proposed cuts to some federal programs are not mere shavings; they are rather deep and harmful to my district spanning Kentucky‚Äôs Appalachian region and other rural, impoverished parts of the country. The Congress has a Constitutional duty to fund the federal government and protect taxpayer spending, and we will uphold that responsibility through the appropriations process for fiscal year 2018.   We will responsibly consider the impact of every component of President Trump‚Äôs blueprint. However, we must ensure that we take care of the less fortunate and protect federal programs, like the Appalachian Regional Commission, that provide vital resources for rural communities and families every year.  Click the link to read more.
NA
Memorial Day 2017 - Remembering our heroes Ì†ºÌ∑∫Ì†ºÌ∑∏

I strongly condemn the cowardly attacks in Kabul ‚Äì another tragic reminder that we must remain ever vigilant in our quest to end violent extremism. Our thoughts and prayers are with those who have suffered at the hands of these terrorists, and also with those who will work to rebuild the Afghan capital in the coming weeks and months. Protecting our diplomats and their families abroad is one of our chief responsibilities, and we remain committed to providing robust resources for embassy security through the appropriations process.

America needs pro-job, pro-energy policies to get our country back on track. Clean coal technology is a critical part of our energy portfolio, but we shouldn't be putting the United States at a competitive disadvantage or make the costs of energy higher for the American people, as the Paris agreement would. President Obama bypassed congressional approval to enter into the climate accord that would force the United States to reduce fossil fuel emissions by 30 percent by the year 2025 and jeopardizes 2.7 million jobs. I applaud President Trump for his decision to begin negotiating a new agreement to support coal production, protect American jobs and spur affordable energy.

Since Kentucky joined the Union 225 years ago, it has birthed incredible leaders and innovators across all socio-economic sectors.   Our men and women have answered the call of duty and braved the front-lines for generations. Our coal miners have powered the country and fueled affordable energy for decades.   Still today, 225 years later, Kentuckians remain resilient in the face of adversity, diligent in innovation and giving with unmatched compassion and hospitality. Thanks to the many successes and valiant pioneers of our past, I believe our best days are ahead of us. Happy 225th Birthday Kentucky!  #####  Check out The Library of Congress Prints & Photographs collection to see Kentucky through the years with prints, photos, publications, cartoons, and more. Explore the full gallery of historic images: go.usa.gov/x56h3  #Kentucky #photos #LibraryofCongress

Earlier today, I had the opportunity to advocate for federal support to revitalize coal country.   During a federal budget hearing for fiscal year 2018 with Secretary Ryan Zinke from the U.S. Department of Interior, I questioned why the agency proposed to eliminate important programs that would support ongoing efforts for economic growth in Central Appalachia.  Specifically, Secretary Zinke's budget would eliminate the Abandoned Mine Land (AML) Pilot Project that has provided a total of $195 million in fiscal years 2016 and 2017 for projects that reclaim abandoned mine lands and create jobs in states hardest hit by the downturn of the coal industry over the last eight years, including Kentucky. Click the link for more information.  House Committee on Appropriations - Republicans
NA

Today, the U.S. House passed the Financial CHOICE Act to support small businesses, spur job creation and rein in the complex Dodd-Frank Act, which contains more regulations than all of the Obama-era regulations combined.   The Financial CHOICE Act is another promise kept to promote job creation across the country through legislation that rescues Main Street, rather than billing taxpayers for bailouts on Wall Street. Community banks across America are closing every day, making lending more difficult for farmers, small start-up companies and businesses that need to expand. This bill protects taxpayers, mobilizes first-time home buyers and gets the American dream for job creators back on track.  The Financial CHOICE Act now heads to the U.S. Senate for consideration.   For more information about the Financial CHOICE Act, visit: https://financialservices.house.gov/choice/

Acting Inspector General of Social Security, is warning citizens about a phone scheme allegedly targeting former clients of Kentucky disability attorney Eric C. Conn.    According to reports, the callers claim to be from SSA and offer citizens $9,000 from a ‚ÄúConn Client Compensation Fund‚Äù if the citizens send $200 to the ‚ÄúFederal Reserve Bank of New York.‚Äù  The number associated with these calls is 202-681-5115.  Those who have sent money have received additional calls; some callers report that citizens can receive greater compensation amounts if they send more money, while others threaten that citizens will be arrested if they do not send additional funds.   The Acting Inspector General is alerting citizens that SSA personnel are not making these calls, and the compensation fund described in the calls does not exist.

Bono visited the Hill today to share his heart for foreign aid through the ONE Campaign and the importance of protecting federal funding for international affairs. He also graciously sang "Happy Birthday" to my wife Cynthia today!

Today, the U.S. House Appropriations Committee approved the federal Defense spending bill for fiscal year 2018. The legislation provides $658.1 billion for the Department of Defense (DoD), including operations, readiness activities, combatting terrorism, and health and quality-of-life programs for U.S. troops and military families.  This bill will strengthen U.S. military forces, improve readiness and boost healthcare for our troops, their families and retirees. We have a duty to equip our men and women on the front lines with the necessary tools and training to aid them in protecting our homeland, supporting our allies overseas, and guarding against violent extremists.

Congratulations to my long-time caseworker and Social Security expert, Sarah Meece, who retired today from our Somerset District Office.   Over the last 36 years, Sarah has worked on approximately 150,000 cases, representing an unmatched record of assistance for more than 4,000 individuals each year.   Sarah gained so much notoriety in her field that staff from other Congressional offices and officials from the Administration regularly contacted her for guidance in casework.   My wife, Cynthia, and I wish Sarah and her husband, Bud, many wonderful years of retirement with their children and grandchildren.
Special thanks to our local Forestry Division Firefighters who are arriving in Arizona today to assist our neighbors out west. Keep up the great work!

Special thanks to Jonathan Barnes (left) for his dedicated work as an educator at the Oneida Baptist Institute for more than a decade, and his heartfelt service as a volunteer and advocate for the ONE Campaign. I wish him the best of luck in his next chapter of life in Georgia.   He is passing the torch on to Bonita and David Robinson (right) in Clay County, who will continue their long-time service for OBI and the ONE Campaign. Keep up the great work!

The House Appropriations Committee today approved the fiscal year 2018 Energy and Water Development, and Related Agencies Appropriations bill on a voice vote. The legislation provides annual funding for national defense nuclear weapons activities, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE), various programs under the Department of Energy (DOE), and other related agencies.   I advocated for provisions to fund the Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC), coal research and development through the National Energy Technology Labs, and to prevent USACE from carrying out a water-supply reallocation study at Lake Cumberland in Kentucky.  This bill responsibly funds our national security interests and builds upon essential infrasture needs across the country. Specifically, this bill protects the ARC from proposed elimination and ensures critical programs will continue in our hardest hit Appalachian coal communities. The bill also prohibits the Corps of Engineers from carrying out its ongoing effort to tax small rural communities that access water in Lake Cumberland in southern Kentucky. I urge my colleagues in the U.S. House of Representatives to support this legislation.  Click the link below to read more>>>

I applaud the House Appropriations Committee and Chairman Frelinghuysen for approving the fiscal year 2018 Commerce, Justice, Science Appropriations Bill. The $56 billion bill funds the Departments of Commerce and Justice, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the National Science Foundation (NSF), and other related agencies.   This bill funds the first comprehensive and holistic attack on deadly opioid overdoses. It has robust funding for the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act (CARA), maintains funding for drug courts and residential substance treatment programs, increases funding for the Prescription Drug Monitoring Program, methamphetamine lab cleanups and youth mentoring programs. This is a wholesale attack on this national epidemic identified by the CDC.   The committee also rejected the Trump Administration's proposal to rescind funding previously secured in fiscal year 2016 for construction of a federal prison in Letcher County.   I'm pleased that funding remains intact for construction of the federal prison in Letcher County, and the project will continue as scheduled.  In addition to comprehensive funding to combat the drug abuse epidemic, I advocated for $30 million to continue economic development assistance for coal mining communities; $95 million for the Bureau of Prisons for construction, acquisition and maintenance of prison facilities; $300 million for Legal Services Corporation, a funding source that has recently assisted victims of the Eric C. Conn fiasco in Eastern Kentucky; and space science research, which will help continue competitive programs at the University of Kentucky and Morehead State University.   Click the link below for more details about the bill.

I applaud the U.S. House Appropriations Committee for approving the fiscal year 2018 federal funding bill for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The legislation provides $44.3 billion for DHS, which includes $1.6 billion to construct a southern border barrier and other security improvements, meeting the full White House request.   The bill targets critical programs such as aviation security, border and immigration enforcement, customs activities, protection against cyberterrorism, natural disaster response, and efforts to stop the smuggling of drugs and people into the U.S.  This bill is a complicated and vital piece of the nation's defense. I wholeheartedly support securing our borders; however, we must do so using these tax dollars wisely, leveraging the right mix of physical security, personnel and technology. Together, we will continue supporting the Department of Homeland Security and its vision of ensuring a homeland that is safe, secure and resilient against terrorism and other hazards.  As Chairman Emeritus of the House Appropriations Committee, Rogers advocated for continued provisions to focus Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Continuing Training Grant funding on training for rural communities, as well as $690 million for the DHS Assistance to Firefighters Grant Program, for which dozens of volunteer fire departments across the country and in southern and eastern Kentucky compete for funding.  The bill now heads to the House floor for consideration.  Click the link below for bill highlights.
NA

This week, the House Appropriations Committee is working to pass the final five remaining appropriations bills to fund federal government operations in fiscal year 2018. The Committee passed two of those bills today, including the Interior and Environment Appropriations Bill. I voted for the legislation, which provides $31.4 billion for Interior and Environment related agencies, including $75 million to continue the Abandoned Mine Lands (AML) Pilot Program to revitalize coal communities.   The funds are targeted to important investments in the nation‚Äôs natural resources, including $3.4 billion for the Department of the Interior and U.S. Forest Service to prevent and combat devastating wildfires. The legislation also contains several policy provisions to rein in harmful and unnecessary regulations at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and other agencies.  I'm very pleased that this bill will continue the successful AML Pilot Program that is actively turning old abandoned mine land into productive areas for job creation, tourism and other economic development projects in our struggling coal-producing states. This bill also cuts more waste in the EPA and focuses funding on providing clean water across the country.  The bill now heads to the House floor for consideration.  Click the link below for bill highlights.

Click here to read my statement about President Trump's new strategy on Afghanistan & South Asia: https://t.co/wjFjDKX1dZ

The men and women of the U.S. Armed Forces have stood fearlessly in the face of terrorism to ensure the horrific bloodshed that took place nearly 16 years ago on September 11th, never happen again on American soil. Since that day, our military leaders have gained valuable experience and intelligence regarding the new evil we face and the unprecedented measures required to prevent future attacks.  I applaud President Trump's determination to defeat terrorism through a new comprehensive strategy that utilizes diplomacy, economic assistance, and our military to deny safe havens for terrorists in Afghanistan and South Asia. With numerous terrorist organizations operating in that region, we must remain vigilant in our national security efforts and learn from past mistakes.  As Chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on State and Foreign Operations, I agree that a winning strategy must include robust diplomacy, responsible foreign assistance, expanded authority and resources for our troops in the field, and strong consequences for any nation that harbors terrorists. I look forward to working with the Administration to ensure that it has the resources necessary to carry out this plan, while also ensuring that we maintain proper oversight on behalf of the American People.

Today, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Make America Secure and Prosperous Appropriations Act for fiscal year 2018.   This bill beefs up our Armed Forces to ensure our brave men and women in uniform are well-equipped to beat back our enemies overseas and keep us safe here at home. It prioritizes our efforts to combat the drug abuse epidemic, providing robust funding for a comprehensive federal response that mirrors Operation UNITE‚Äôs successful three-pronged strategy in Kentucky.  The bill also includes important resources to reinvigorate the economy in our rural coal communities ‚Äì including strong funding for the Appalachian Regional Commission and another $30 million for the AML pilot program in Kentucky. I have secured two years of funding for this important effort to reclaim and repurpose abandoned mine land to create jobs and long-term opportunities.   I‚Äôm optimistic this important legislation will be signed into law before the end of the year so we can continue to build on our progress in Southern and Eastern Kentucky.  Click the link below to learn about Kentucky benefits in the bill.
Today, the House passed the FY18 Make America Secure & Prosperous Approps Act. Learn how it will impact Kentucky ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/9XJa6MBoyC

The Appalachian Regional Commission has a critical task‚Äîto improve the lives of those who live across Appalachia. However, every President over the past four decades has worked to abolish the ARC, questioning things like waste and mismanagement at the agency, so it‚Äôs time for reform. Senator McConnell and I structured this legislation to bring clear direction to the ARC, reviving its core mission to boost economic development and reduce poverty in our most distressed Appalachian counties through meaningful projects.   Over the years, the ARC has provided a lifeline for vital programs in our communities, from connecting more families to clean water and sewer, to now helping rural communities transition into the complex digital economy. The bill refocuses their efforts and repositions the ARC directly in its service area to reduce operating expenses and provide better communication about needs in the region.  Click the link below to read more.

Next month Liberia is expected to hold its first peaceful, democratic transition of power in over 70 years, thanks in-large-part to President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf who has displayed remarkable leadership over the last 12 years. During her Excellency's service, she earned the U.S. Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Nobel Peace Prize. As Chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on State and Foreign Operations, it was an honor to meet with her on Monday to discuss foreign aid for our allied nation.

You may remember the incredible story of this young lady, Malala Yousafzai, who survived an assassination attempt by a Taliban gunman who boarded her school bus and shot her on the way to school. It happened in 2012 when she was only 15 years old. Since then, she has traveled around the world advocating for education for young girls in developing countries, including her homeland of Pakistan. To enhance her efforts, she launched the Malala Fund and the "YesAllGirls" campaign for education. In 2014, Malala became the youngest person ever and the first Pakistani to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Most recently, she was appointed as a United Nations Messenger of Peace to promote girls education and was accepted to Oxford University to continue her own studies. It was an honor to meet with Malala to discuss USAID for education and learn about her future plans.

Today, the U.S. House fought to protect the Second Amendment by passing a bill to eliminate confusion about different gun laws across state lines. The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017 will allow a qualified person with a concealed carry permit to bring their firearm to other states where they are allowed. The legislation will make it easier for law-abiding Kentuckians to carry their authorized firearms with them when they travel across state lines.
